newsitem.title: GREECE: SIMITIS PROMISES HIGHER PENSISONS FOR FARMERS.
newsitem.headline: SIMITIS PROMISES HIGHER PENSISONS FOR FARMERS.

text.p: Greek Prime Minister Costas Simitis unveiled his plans for farmers and small firms promising higher pensions, free medical and pharmaceutical care for farmers and lower social insurance premiums to firms for new hirings of young people.

The Organisation of Farmers Insurance (OGA) will become a main insurance fund and provide farmers with decent pensions comparable to those of other funds starting in 1997, Simitis told a press conference.
He promised that his socialist PASOK party, if elected, will apply a living cost clause to farmers' lower basic pensions to protect their purchasing power.
He announced that pensioners will receive a 4,000 drachma compensation in January for inflation in the period September 1995 to December 1996.
The financing will come from insurance contributions by farmers, state budget contributions and returns earned on OGA's reserves, he said.
The Greek Premier also said the state would pay for a system of social care for pensioners and link low pensions with expected inflation.
The objective criteria for taxable income calculations will be removed when the automated tax system (TAXIS) is fully operational, said Simitis.
Firms hiring young people below the age of 23 or below the age of 27 for university graduates will pay two percent less in insurance premiums annually for the first two years, he said.

Simitis boasted that socialists gave subsidies of 380 billion drachmas to small sized firms from 1994 to date against 118 billion drachmas by the conservatives between 1991 and 1993. --Dimitris Kontogiannis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
